narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained foundational knowledge of Kant's philosophy.

This course was a thorough treatment of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason. We read Kant's notoriously difficult text, made an effort to correctly interpret it ourselves through short exegetical papers, and evaluated Kant's claims. We examined almost the entire Critique, from Kant's Introduction, Transcendental Aesthetic/Deduction, Analogies of Experience, and the Transcendental Doctrine of Elements (Paralogisms, Antinomies, etc.). We explored in great detail the Supreme Principle and conditioning relations in Kant.
Learnt about Kant's Critique, how to do historical philosophy, metaphysics and epistemology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Overall, the course was fantastic. Given the time constraint of a semester, I don't know if there is any room for improvement.

I enjoyed everything about the course. Professor Watkins' explanation of the Critique was so helpful; especially by the end of the course, I felt as though I was really beginning to understand Kant (as well as anyone can). I'm so happy to have taken this course--Professor Watkins provided the guidance that anyone wanting to study Kant desperately needs. I will also add that Prof. Watkins really conveyed his enthusiasm for Kant, and it was difficult not to be super excited about Kant like him!

Strengths
1. Very clear and thorough lectures
2. Kant's fascinating metaphysical and epistemological approach
3. Lots of opportunities to practice doing historical philosophy

Weaknesses:
1. Unfortunately due to time, we didn't get to discuss some of the most interesting implications of Kant's philosophy

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If any of my friends decide to go to UCSD and are interested in Kant, I would send them Professor Watkins way.

Yes! I think this course is a NECESSITY for any philosophy major, or anyone interested in Kant (Don't try and tackle Kant on your own!). The course equips one with the necessary background and basic understanding that one needs for further study/understanding of Kant.

Yes. Kant's transcendental idealism changes your whole view of how metaphysics and epistemology can be done, and especially if you don't have a lot of knowledge of the history of philosophy, it gives you a really good sense of the major debates and approaches of philosophers in Kant's time. As well, learning metaphysics and epistemology as part of Kant's system, as opposed to in a contemporary class, is often more satisfying, because it tries to give you an explanation for everything that you've wondered about and not just a particular narrow or specific question.

extras.title: GMAN 381 01/PHIL 204 01 - Kant's Critique of Pure Reason
